title: Concentration and fragmentation of OECD member countries’ bilateral adaptation aid.
authors: Figure 1. Concentration and fragmentation of OECD member countries’ bilateral adaptation aid. Scatterplot of donor countries according to their number of recipient countries and their number of areas to be fostered by their action. Source : OECD StatExtracts. Date : Jan 6 2014

sections.html:
Step 1

The map enables to compare the funding policies of OECD member countries, not only  by comparing the amount of money they are wishing to spend for the adaptation of recipient countries, but also by visualizing two other parameters : whether their aid tend to be concentrated on a few number of recipient countries or spread out on a large number of countries (x-axis), and whether their aid tend to be concentrated on a few number of areas to be fostered or spread out on a large number of areas (y-axis).

Thus one can observe common patterns or specificities among donor countries, irrespective of whether they give away large amounts of money for adaptation or smaller amounts.

Step 2

Moreover, when rolling over a particular country, one can visualize the amount of bilateral aid they committed for adaptation between 2010 and 2012 and their top 5 recipient countries.

Figure 2. Concentration and fragmentation of OECD member countries’ bilateral adaptation aid. When rolling over a particular donor countries, the amount of money committed by this country and its top 5 recipient countries are shown on the right side of the scatterplot. Source : OECD StatExtracts. Date : Jan 6 2014
sections.title: How to read the map

sections.html:
The data are extracted from the OECD StatExtracts database (stats.oecd.org) which collects general Official Development Assistance (ODA) and is reported OECD Development Assistance Committee by member countries. We identified aid that was labelled through the RioMarkers and selected only projects that had been categorised with adaptation as their principal objective (score 2).  As the RioMarker “adaptation” was implemented in 2010, we have only used data beginning from that year in order to identify adaptation-related projects. We summed the amounts of USD committed and adjusted for inflation for the three years between 2010 and 2012.

We then extracted the number of recipient countries by donor country, as well as the names of their top 5 recipient countries. The recipient countries’ fields “bilateral, unspecified” or regions/groups of countries have been taken out of the results.

As far as the “areas to be fostered” are concerned, we utilized the purpose names which qualify each of the project in the OECD database: according to http://www.oecd.org/dac/stats/purposecodessectorclassification.htm, “sector coding identifies the specific areas of the recipient’s economic or social development the transfer intends to foster.” In this map we are interested only in the number each donor country utilizes.
sections.title: How the map is built (map building protocol)

sections.html:
The United States report insignificant adaptation-labelled aid in term of amount (precise amount???), areas (which ones???) and recipient countries (Haiti, Marshall Islands and Algeria). Either they undercode adaptation money (do not declare it as adaptation money), or they do not  report it via OECD but e.g. via USAid.

On the contrary, Japan (the first donor country) has been flagged as over-reporting climate change adaptation money.

Of course, countries which commit less adaptation aid tend to give to less recipients countries and less areas.

The Netherlands concentrates its aid on few countries and few areas. The same is true of EU institutions.

It can be interesting to compare the Netherlands, Korea and Spain: their total amount of aid is in the same range (???) and their place on the scatterplot is different. The number of recipient countries of the Netherlands and Korea are similar so they are aligned vertically. The number of areas of Korea and Spain are similar, so they are aligned horizontally. However overall the funding policy of Spain tends to be most scattered among countries and, to a lesser extent, areas. This makes is totally different from the Netherlands.

Germany, Canada and Japan and the United Kingdom have similar concentration patterns, even though the amount of money they contribute is different. Another group is formed of Australia, Italy, Switzerland, France and Norway.
sections.title: Finding 01

sections.html:
Former colonial powers tend to aid more countries that were part of their empire, like France, which has got Cameroon, Gabon and Vietnam among their top 5 recipient countries, Belgium (Democratic Republic of Congo) or the United Kingdom (Bangladesh, India and Nepal). However, this is not always true : Indonesia is not among the top 5 recipients of the Netherlands, but is the first recipient of Denmark.

Regional ties do also play a role. New Zealand commits adaptation aid to Samoa, the Cook Islands and Papua New Guinea, none of them being in the top 5 recipient countries of any other donor.
